review.title: Criticality & Deep Learning I: Generally Weighted Nets
review.abstract: Motivated by the idea that criticality and universality of phase transitions might play a crucial role in achieving and sustaining learning and intelligent behaviour in biological and artificial networks, we analyse a theoretical and a pragmatic experimental set up for critical phenomena in deep learning. On the theoretical side, we use results from statistical physics to carry out critical point calculations in feed-forward/fully connected networks, while on the experimental side we set out to find traces of criticality in deep neural networks. This is our first step in a series of upcoming investigations to map out the relationship between criticality and learning in deep networks.

metadata.title: Criticality and Deep Learning, Part I: Theory vs. Empirics

sections.text: Motivated by the idea that criticality and universality of phase transitions could play a crucial role in achieving and maintaining learning and intelligent behavior in biological and artificial networks, we are analyzing a theoretical and a pragmatic experimental setup for critical phenomena in deep learning. On the theoretical side, we are using results from statistical physics to perform critical point calculations in feed-forward / fully networked networks, while on the experimental side, we are looking for traces of criticality in deep neural networks. This is our first step in a series of upcoming studies to show the relationship between criticality and learning in deep networks.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Different systems in nature exhibit patterns, shapes, attractors, and recurrent behavior that are not caused by law per se; the ubiquity of such systems and similar statistical properties of their exhibit order has led to the term "universality," since such phenomena are manifested in cosmology [1], chemical and physical systems [2], landscapes, biological predator systems, and endless others [3]. Furthermore, most simplified mathematical models show the same statistical properties when their parameters are adjusted correctly. As such, it is sufficient to study N particle systems with simple, "atomic" components and interactions, since they exhibit many non-trivial properties that lie within the large N boundary.

sections.heading: 5 Summary and outlook
sections.text: Summary: In this article, we take our first steps in investigating the relationship between criticality and deep learning networks. After a brief introduction to criticality in statistical physics and real networks, we started with the theoretical construction of a fully networked layer. We used continuous techniques to approach the medium field to tackle the partition function of the system, and ended with a system of differential equations that determine the critical behavior of the system. These equations can be the starting point for a possible network architecture with induced criticality and learning rules that exploit criticality. Afterwards, we presented results of experiments aimed at finding traces of power-law distributions in current deep learning networks such as multilayered feed-forward networks, revolutionary networks and autoencoders. Results - with the exception of the autoencoder - were affirmative in a negative sense, next building the need to create networks with induced criticism and learning rules that exploit the critical state.
